Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2008 08:15PM vhqh wrote: Don't let the statistics get to you, YOU ARE NOT A STATISTIC!  Also keep in mind that all statistics are outdated.....they spend several years gatthers information, several more years compiling it and coming up with their figures before finally releasing it to the public.  End result is that the statistics you see can be 5 to 10 years old by the time you read them.  Great advances have been made in the past few years and more are on the way.  Talk to your doctor about your desire to skip the biopsy, with it being classified as Birads 5 they might be inclined to go along with you.  I know my onc made some assumptions about me that he soon learned weren't accurate, be clear about what you want.  {{{{{{{{{HUGS}}}}}}}}}

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 12:49PM vhqh wrote: I appreciate everyone's help, I'm doing better today, broke the news to one of my sisters and she didn't freak out, she actually reminded me of one of my Mom's CTs that showed brain lesions that they didn't know where they came from.  My CT showed a number of enhancing nodules, most very small although there were 3 that were around 1 cm.  I am asymptomatic so that is in my favor as I do not want to quit working, not yet anyway.  I do have family and coworkers who will help me out with transportation and I am sure I can make arrangements for my horses, I just hate to impose on people.   I am very stubborn and independent, I was doing ok until I talked to the rad onc Thursday and she took the attitude that it was brain mets despite the fact that she isn't convinced that my femur met is actually a met since it wasn't biopsied.  We only had a CT on the brain, the femur was verified with a MRI, PET and xray, seems to me she would accept the femur as a met, especially since it has changed from osteolytic to osteoblastic!  She did say that as small as the lesions are they should be controllable although WBR is pretty scary.  She was not happy to find I am still driving, she also told me to quit work, I lost my temper a little and informed her I was not going to quit living because of this crap.  That took her back a bit, she looked at me and said "Martha, you're an amazing patient!".     I will get the results of the brain MRI, PET and CA 27-29 Tuesday, I will also finish up rad boosts to the mastectomy site and axilla next week.  Last week was the one year anniversary of my diagnosis, I was really looking forward to getting a break from things.......

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2008 08:00PM vhqh wrote: When I was in high school, my mother was diagnosed with colon cancer, we'd lost Dad 3 years before that to stomach cancer.  Being the youngest and the only one left at home, I drove Mom to all her appointments and chemo sessions, I wasn't even 16 yet.  The chemo SE was horrid and nearly killed her a couple of times yet she hung on.  It was to the point that we just hoped to get to the car before the vomiting started.  They finally stopped one drug after it got to the point she needed hospitalization nearly every month.  Mom recovered and is still alive today.  She is my inspiration, I know that I haven't gone through near the hell she did so I tell myself I still have a lot of options open to me.  I do worry about it though since the brain mets diagnosis, I've tolerated treatment very well so far but the future possibilties scare the crap out of me.  I honestly don't know how Mom did it but I'm hoping maybe it is the same stubborn hard headedness that I have. I honestly don't know if this story really helps you at all or even makes sense, but I thought you might want a kids perspective.  I was thoroughly grossed out by much of this experience yet I wasn't about to shirk helping but like most teens my attitude wasn't always the best either.  You may be sick and in bed but don't you believe that this means you're not there for them.  I am much much closer to my mother than my siblings as a result of this but there are times now that I wonder if she ever wanted to stop.  {{{{{{{{{{{ HUGS }}}}}}}}}}}} Martha

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 06:28PM vhqh wrote: My most recent PET included the brain and brain mets can be picked but PET is not very reliable for this.  I have brain mets and my PET came back clean.  I suspect part of the reason is that a lesion must reach a certain size before PET will pick up on it, mine were all 1 cm or smaller.  The big problem is that PET uses radioactive sugar which is taken up as fuel by the most active cells, there is so much activity going on in the brain that it generally lights up throughout it.  MRI is the preferred scan for the brain but a CT can also pick up brain mets.

Posts.Title: "Orinine"? Kleenex

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 09:34PM - edited Oct 28, 2008 09:35PM by vhqh I started rads to the mastectomy area in mid August, when that was done I immediately started whole brain radiation and will not finish until next Friday, only 8 more (out of 50 total) to go!!!  They don't like to give sessions of rads that close together but in my case there really wasn't any other option.  I have had some fatigue but have not missed any work yet because of it.  Each person is different and until you get into it there is no way to tell how you'll react.  I am fair skinned and I had some burning but not anything too serious, biggest problem was where my soft cotton Tshirts rubbed at the neck line. If you get tired, take a nap or go to bed earlier, it's time to be nice to your body.  Use the aquaphor or aloe or whatever creme is recommended by your rad onc, and use it as much as you want to but no less than twice a day, three would be better.  Mine insisted that I used nothing but corn starch until they told me differently, then they gave me Aquaphor.  I did not wash mine off before reapplying, friction is not good on radiated skin.  Ask for Silvadene if you get any raw spots or blisters, it worked wonders for me.  I was not totally compliant with my rad onc instructions as I used aloe right after treatment instead of the Aquaphor due to the greasiness and the fact I go directly back to work, unexpected side benefit is that aloe acted as a deodorant for me, no BO once I started using it. Once I started treatment, deodorant and bras were forbidden, I was not allowed to use anything at all on my skin prior to my zaps.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2008 11:42PM vhqh wrote: I was officially diagnosed yesterday with scattered brain mets.  I've been doing a lot of research since the lesions were first spotted on a CT a week ago and one statement I've seen several times that has given me hope is that despite the dire sound of having brain mets, most do not die from them.  How well your cancer is controlled from the neck down has a big impact on your prognosis with the brain mets.  Tykerb, xeloda and temodor are all believed to cross the blood brain barrier so there is more than just radiation available however radiation is still the primary treatment.  With scattered mets like mine, it's going to be whole brain, I start Monday and I am dreading it.  I will continue with herceptin, zometa, and tamoxifen, once done with radiation we will add tykerb.  My femur lesion is healing and I have no confirmed mets anywhere else below the neck so I am hoping to be one who can beat the odds.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 02:56PM vhqh wrote: Herceptin is a very good targeted therapy if your mother is HER2 +, otherwise it is useless.  It is frequently used alone or along with other treatments but I don't believe they use it in place of other drugs, Tykerb is an exception to this as it is the only other targeted therapy I am aware of that also targets the HER2+ receptors.  I would suggest visiting the HER2 or Chemo forums on this site for more help.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 10:21PM vhqh wrote: I also started a week ago Thursday, round number 7 today, I will be having 28 tx and 5 boosts.  No problems or side effects yet, I have been a little tired but I'm not sure it's treatment related or allergies or just staying up too late...... :) I would suggest not buying anything in advance until you find out exactly what they are going to allow you to use.  I was told absolutely no bras after the 1st tx, onc really frowned on my prosthesis which was a lightly weighted swim puff.  No creams or gels or deodorant other than 100% corn starch, clean and dry is the goal.  Nothing, including corn starch, before treatment as any residue will aggravate the skin reaction.  When I start having problems they will give me what they want me to use.  I was given no instructions regarding what soap to use although I did go ahead and buy some Dove. Simulation didn't take too long, maybe 30 minutes on the table.  My only problem was a crick in my neck from having to lay still with my head turned to the side.  The xray machine is built into the radiation machine but on a separate "arm", they will move the arms around you while you lie on the table.  Be prepared for ink transfer from their artwork.  Also don't be surprised if they turn the lights on and off, they use lasers mounted on the walls and my tattoos to line me up in the same position each time.  For the actual treatment a very flexible rubber like mat is laid on my chest "to concentrate the radiation".  Treatment is quick, I am in and out in less than 15 minutes.  They were able to work with my schedule, I go to work at 6:30, leave for treatment at 8:15 and am back before 9:00.  This meshs with my daily routine perfectly.  On Thursdays I see the radiation onc, I Wednesdays I have a CBC drawn.

Had a busy morning getting an echo, CT and bone scan prior to radiation, even though I didn't have a set time for radiation the techs were right there holding the door open for me when I walked in!  It's a small satelite cancer center and I really like it, the main center in the city is just too big and busy for my tastes.  I have 2 female and 1 male tech, one of the females just came back from an extended leave so for the most part the male has been in there.  Like someone else already said, I'm getting so used to baring it all that I have had to remind myself to finish buttoning up my shirt before walking out of the dressing room.  It's kind of funny but I am not nearly as selfconcious about the unreconstructed mastectomy side as I am about the good "natural" side. Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2008 09:37PM - edited Jul 6, 2008 09:41PM by vhqh My initial CT showed liver lesions, the bone scan was clean.  They then sent me for a PET to check the status of my liver, those lesions appear to be benign but a met in my femur lit up.  A MRI was done which showed severe thinning in my femur, this thinning was proved to be false by an xray.  The second PET scan did not get a clear look at the femur due to generalized tissue uptake in the thigh, probably due to having walked all over the hospital trying to find where they moved the PET machine to, I guess they are serious when they say not to exercise a day or two beforehand.  My personal opinion is to get all the scans you can done, this beast is a sneaky devil and the more ways you look for it the harder it is for it to hide. I don't have a whole lot of confidence in my radiologist, not once has he commented on a femur lesion on my CT yet they guy who read the second PET made reference to the met appearing to correspond with a lesion visible on the CT?!?  On both bone scans I was able to look at it on the computer and noticed a lighter area where this met is, the radiologists admitted that there was "in retrospect" some uptake on the first bone scan but gave no indication of seeing it at all on the second, to my untrained eye I could see it much clearer on the second scan.  Needless to say I am giving strong consideration to driving to a much bigger hospital for my next round of scans just to get a different set of eyes reviewing them.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 12:05AM vhqh wrote: The big thing is that she MAY have cancer, until they do an actual biopsy they don't know for sure.  About 80% of lumps will back negative, so don't assume too much even though I know it's hard to do at this stage.  It sounds like you are both at one of the worst points, where you're scared witless and don't have any answers. About the only thing I can suggest right now is try and help your Mom out as much as possible to reduce her stress.  Run the sweeper or do some cleaning for her without being asked, help fix supper for the family or maybe see if you can take her out for some ice cream or a "chick" flick.  I'm sure you're busy with school but it doesn't have to be something big, just little things to let her know you are thinking about her and trying to ease things.  Whatever you do, don't let it affect your grades, I"m sure she wouldn't like that at all.  Martha

Posts.Title: Frequency of Scans/Tests rkt vhqh

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2008 05:21PM vhqh wrote: Anything below 38 is considered good for a CA 27 29, small fluctuations are normal, an overall upward trend would be of concern.  PET or CT either one will look at your liver, since your schedule says PET/CT I would bet you are getting the combined version which is better than the separate ones.  It doesn't surprise me that the instructions just refer to PET since the restrictions for PET are far more stringent than that for a CT.  The CT provides a clearer picture, the PET detects activity.  My first CT detected liver lesions, the subsequent PET showed that these were benign.  PET is also limited in the size of the activity it can pick up on.  My theory is to look at the big picture, my CA 27-29 is at 13.5 yet I was just diagnosed with brain mets.  CT and MRI picked up on them, largest was only 1 cm and the PET did not detect it.  The bone scan repeatedly missed my femur lesion until it started healing, PET scan picked it up every time until now that it is healing.  MRI showed severe thinning in the bone, plain old xray proved this to be false.  All tests have their limitations, you have to look at everthing within context.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2008 02:18PM - edited Aug 30, 2008 10:58AM by vhqh I had the exact same treatment, ended it in February after 5 rounds due to the good response.  I did chemo on Thursdays and got the Nuelasta on Friday.  The first round I started feeling a little down on Sunday but worked half days Monday and Tuesday, resuming a full day schedule on Wednesday.  Round 2 was a disaster as I came down with a flu bug right after treatment and was off work for the entire following week.  By round 3 the fatigue was setting in pretty good and I took Monday and Tuesday off, rounds 4 and 5 I took Monday through Wednesday off the following week.  After the 5th round it literally wiped me out just to take a shower.  Although queasy at times, full blown nausea was limited to only a couple of isolated incidents.  I had very little tingling and the only constipation came the week I had the flu so who knows what caused which symptoms.  I will be getting the Herceptin indefinitely but I've not had any side effects with it.  edited to add - I really could have worked most of the days that I took off other than the week I had the flu but I had plenty of leave time on the books so I didn't push myself to go in.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2008 09:04PM vhqh wrote: I have horses also, currently down to 7.  I don't have stalls, 2 were on a small pasture and the balance were on dry lot.  I live in town, the horses were 15 miles out on the farm.  Prior to diagnosis, I went out daily to grain and check them.  Hay is big round bales and I have my own bale buggy to move them with.  After diagnosis I adjusted things considerably in how I care for them.  I would put 2 bales out at a time for the ones on dry lot, this would last them for about a week.  Daily trips out were eliminated, depending on how I felt I went either every other or every third day.  Grain of course was cut back to small amounts on the days I went out but they had hay access 24/7.  The neighbor I bought the hay from voluntarily started delivering and setting out the hay for me at no extra charge after the exhaustion from chemo set in.  The two on pasture were older horses that really needed the extra calories grain could provide but I started putting out Chrystalyx lick tubs and they did good on them.  This was winter time, I started chemo in November and finished it in February of this year.  I am in Kansas which of course has considerably different weather than Florida.  The drastic reduction in care I made may seem neglectful to some but this is ranch country and a pretty common level situation.  Horses evolved to eat forage and can generally get by just fine with free choice good quality grass hay which I made sure that they had.  Due to the escalating price of gas and feed, I have not returned to daily trips out and feeding grain.  I am single and live alone, having the horses depending on me forced me to get out and get exercise, even when I didn't feel up to doing much.  I really didn't worry about the possibility of infection from the horses, the people you have everyday contact with are a much bigger threat.  Of course I wore good foot wear, I don't think I'd want to run the risk of stepping on something in flip flops while on chemo.  I also showered as soon as I got home.  Unless you have family or someone else who can help you, I would strongly recommend you figure out a minimum level of care acceptable to maintain your horses health with the facilities you have available.  Also figure out what to eliminate first if needed.  This way, as you progress through treatment you will already know what steps to take as you go should the side effects start getting you down without the stress of trying to figure out what to do.  I cannot give you any lymphadema advice as I have had no problems, I do try to avoid repetetive movement on that side but that's it.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 09:28PM vhqh wrote: If you have a lumpectomy you will need radiation, with a mastectomy you may not have to do radiation but I suspect with you having it in your nodes they will still want you to do the radiation.  I had a lumpectomy but the margins were not clean, then they found the met so I went straight to chemo.  After chemo I had a mastectomy followed by radiation.  Don't be afraid of radiation, it is doable, biggest complaint seems to be fatigue. Usually they will not do a MRI unless they are targeting a specific area.  Every 3 months I have had either a full body bone scan or a bone survey, CT of the chest, abdomin and pelvis and a echo cardiogram (HER2 +++).  Every 6 months I have a PET done.  Not all doctors believe in PET scans, they do have a high rate of false positive readings.  Since the diagnoses of brain mets in September, a MRI of the brain has been added to the 3 month cycle.
Posts.Title: Questions from a first timer lovinmomma lovinmomma

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2008 06:17AM - edited Aug 31, 2008 06:20AM by vhqh I live alone and have gone through a lumpectomy, chemo and mastectomy with very little help.  I have family and friends willing to help but I didn't feel I needed it too much other than driving to the hospital and back for surgery.  The biggest help I accepted was from my hay supplier, I have horses and it was last winter when I did chemo.  He delivered and set out hay for me and refused my offer to pay extra for the delivery.  Living alone and NOT being known as the greatest housekeeper, it was no big deal if the dishes didn't get done for a couple of days or the sweeping wasn't done.  Chemo was the worst thing that got me down and even then I functioned pretty good, working full time except for the first week following treatment when I usually took part of the week off.  I drove myself to all my treatments and would have driven myself to surgery if they would have allowed it.  I did not have reconstruction though, from what I understand you would be much more limited after surgery than I was after my simple mastectomy.  Here we have a "General Public Transportation" van that you can set up transportation to and from things like doctors appointments and grocery shopping.  It started out as a senior citizens service but I believe they had to open it up for everyone due to discrimination laws.  I know of some local churches who have volunteers that will drive people to doctors appointments also.  Where I work our Wellness Committee would have stepped up to provide transport if I needed it plus I had several coworkers who would have done it in a heartbeat if I asked.  I am in a smaller city, population 15,000, we do not have taxi service or bus servince running regular routes. Talk to the people at your cancer center or your hospital social worker to see if there are any organized groups in your area.  Also contact your local chapter of the American Cancer Society, they have monthly support groups here.  Don't panic about doing this alone, it is doable and actually can have it's advantages, sleep when you want to, don't clean if you don't feel like it, etc.

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 06:46PM vhqh wrote: The clip will likely be done with a hollow needle, I know they left one in me after the core biopsy was done to identify the site of the biopsy.  They used this clip when they placed the wire for the wire guided lumpectomy.  Incision was very small, about 1/4 inch, and I wouldn't expect anything different for your clip placement.  They may use ultrasound or the mamo machine to verify placement of the clip, I don't know if they will do this while you are out or not, it could be done either way.  My sentinal node was positive so they took out 11 nodes total, incision was about 2 1/2 inches long.  Steri strips were used to close it and a dressing was put on top of that.  I tend to have allergic reactions to tape, a plain old fashioned bandaid will literally eat my skin off.  After the lumectomy and node disection I also reacted some to the steri strips where in the past I have not.  Please let the surgeon know if you react to tape or bandages, there are alternatives they can use.
